sen.j: 坂戸城（さかとじょう）は、新潟県南魚沼市に存在した大規模な山城。
sen.e: Sakato-jo Castle was a large-scaled yamashiro (a castle located on a mountain) that existed in Minamiuonuma City, Niigata Prefecture.
Sakato-jo Castle was a large-scaled yamashiro (a castle located on a mountain) that existed in Minamiuonuma City, Niigata Prefecture.
Sakato-jo Castle was a large-scaled yamashiro (a castle located on a mountain) that existed in Minamiuonuma City, Niigata Prefecture.

sen.j: 坂戸山山頂（標高634メートル）に本丸、麓に平時の住居跡の遺構が見られる。
sen.e: Ancient structural remnants of Honmaru (the keep of the castle) are located at the top of Sakato-yam Mountain, and those of residences used in peacetime at the foot of the mountain.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Ancient structural remnants of the Honmaru (the keep of the castle) are located at the top of Sakato-yama Mountain, and those of residences used in peacetime can be found at the foot of the mountain.
Ancient structural remnants of the Honmaru (the keep of the castle) are located at the top of Sakato-yama Mountain, and those of residences used in peacetime can be found at the foot of the mountain.

sen.j: 魚野川をはさんで、三国街道を見下ろす交通上の要地に位置する。
sen.e: Across the Uono-gawa River, the castle was located at a strategic point of transportation that commanded a view of the Mikuni-kaido road.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Spanning the Uono-gawa River, the castle was located at a strategic transportation point that commanded a view of the Mikuni-kaido road.
Spanning the Uono-gawa River, the castle was located at a strategic transportation point that commanded a view of the Mikuni-kaido road.

sen.j: 1979年（昭和54年）6月11日、国の史跡に指定された。
sen.e: On June 11, 1979, the area was designated as a national historic site.
On June 11, 1979, the area was designated as a national historic site.
On June 11, 1979, the area was designated as a national historic site.

sen.j: 上田長尾家ゆかりの城として知られており、長尾政景や上杉景勝、直江兼続の居城として名高い。
sen.e: It is known that the castle is related to the Ueda Nagao family, and the castle is also famous as the one that Masakage NAGAO, Kagekatsu UESUGI and Kanetsugu NAOE used as their bases.
It is known that the castle is connected to the Ueda Nagao family, and the castle is also famous as the one that Masakage NAGAO, Kagekatsu UESUGI and Kanetsugu NAOE used as a base.
It is known that the castle is connected to the Ueda Nagao family, and the castle is also famous as the one that Masakage NAGAO, Kagekatsu UESUGI and Kanetsugu NAOE used as a base.

sen.j: 上杉謙信の姉仙桃院（せんとういん）の嫁ぎ先でもある。
sen.e: Sento-in, a sister of Kenshin UESUGI (older than Kenshin), lived there after her marriage as well.
Sento-in, an elder sister of Kenshin UESUGI, lived there after her marriage.
sen.cmt: Changed for clarity and made more formal.
sen.e: Sento-in, an older sister of Kenshin UESUGI, lived there after her marriage.
sen.cmt: 用語リストに従って、「姉」elder sister→older sisterにしました。

sen.j: また上杉景勝が会津へ移され、かわって堀氏が越後に入ると、堀直寄が坂戸城主を務めたことで知られる。
sen.e: It is known that after Kagekatsu UESUGI was moved to Aizu and the Hori clan moved to Echigo, Naoyori HORI became the lord of the Sakato-jo Castle.
It is known that after Kagekatsu UESUGI was moved to Aizu and the Hori clan moved to Echigo, Naoyori HORI became the lord of the castle.
sen.cmt: Name removed as clear rom the context.
sen.e: It is known that after Kagekatsu UESUGI was moved to Aizu and the Hori clan moved to Echigo, Naoyori HORI became the lord of the castle.

sen.j: 中世越後の魚沼郡南部（南魚沼郡）には上田荘があり、鎌倉時代頃には清和源氏流新田氏一族の勢力下にあった。
sen.e: In the medieval period, Ueda-sho Manor existed in the southern part of Uonuma County (present Minami-Uonuma County), and around the Kamakura period, the area was under control of the Nitta clan in the Seiwa-Genji (Minamoto clan) line.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In the medieval period, Ueda-sho Manor was in the southern part of Uonuma County (present Minami-Uonuma County), and around the Kamakura Period, the area was under the control of the Nitta clan of the Seiwa-Genji (Minamoto clan) line.

In the medieval period, Ueda-sho Manor was in the southern part of Uonuma County (present Minami-Uonuma County), and around the Kamakura Period, the area was under the control of the Nitta clan of the Seiwa-Genji (Minamoto clan) line.

sen.j: 当時、荘の中心を扼する坂戸山に城郭が築かれていたものとも推定されるが、本格的な造営は南北朝時代 (日本)にはいって以降のことと考えられている。
sen.e: Although it is supposed that at that time, a castle had already been built on Sakato-yama Mountain placed at the center of the manor, it is considered that it was in the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (in Japan) or later that the castle was been constructed on a large scale.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Although it is supposed that a castle had already been built on Sakato-yama Mountain at this time, placed at the center of the manor, it is considered that it was in the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan) or later that the castle was constructed on a large scale.

Although it is supposed that a castle had already been built on Sakato-yama Mountain at this time, placed at the center of the manor, it is considered that it was in the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan) or later that the castle was constructed on a large scale.

sen.j: 南北朝動乱において、北朝方に立った上杉氏は、越後国南部から南朝方に属した新田氏らを放逐した。
sen.e: In the period of the Northern and Southern Courts, the Uesugi clan supported the Northern Court and ousted the Nitta can and others who supported the Southern Court.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In the period of the Northern and Southern Courts, the Uesugi clan supported the Northern Court and ousted the Nitta can and others who supported the Southern Court.

In the period of the Northern and Southern Courts, the Uesugi clan supported the Northern Court and ousted the Nitta clan and others who supported the Southern Court from the southern part of Echigo Province.
sen.cmt: スペル、「越後の国南部から」の部分を追加。

sen.j: 上杉憲顕のときに越後の守護に任じられた。
sen.e: The Uesugi clan was appointed to Shugo (provincial constable) of Echigo in the era of Noriaki UESUGI.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The Uesugi clan was appointed to the position of Shugo (provincial constable) of Echigo in the era of Noriaki UESUGI.
The Uesugi clan was appointed to the position of Shugo (provincial constable) of Echigo in the era of Noriaki UESUGI.

sen.j: その家臣長尾高景の一族の者が、文和年間（1352年-1355年）に上田荘を領し、上田長尾氏を称して、坂戸山を居城にした。
sen.e: Then a family member of Takakage NAGAO, a vassal of Noriaki, became to own Ueda-sho Manor in the era of 1352 to 1355, called himself as the UEDA NAGAO clan and used the castle on Sakato-yama Mountain as his base.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Following this, a family member of Takakage NAGAO, a vassal of Noriaki, came to own Ueda-sho Manor between 1352 and 1355, called himself of the UEDA NAGAO clan and used the castle on Sakato-yama Mountain as his base.

Following this, a family member of Takakage NAGAO, a vassal of Noriaki, came to own Ueda-sho Manor between 1352 and 1355, called himself of the UEDA NAGAO clan and used the castle on Sakato-yama Mountain as his base.

sen.j: このように伝承される。
sen.e: What is described above is a story handed down orally.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The information above has been handed down orally.
The information above has been handed down orally.

sen.j: こののち上田長尾氏は、守護代の長尾氏とならんで越後国に枢要な位置を占めた。
sen.e: After this, the UEDA NAGAO clan, together with the Nagao clan, Shugodai (deputy of Shugo, provincial constable), occupied important positions in Echigo Province.
After this, the UEDA NAGAO clan, together with the Nagao clan, who were the Shugodai (deputy of the Shugo), occupied important positions in Echigo Province.
After this, the UEDA NAGAO clan, together with the Nagao clan, who were the Shugodai (deputy of the Shugo), occupied important positions in Echigo Province.

sen.j: その居城である坂戸城は、越後府中（現在の上越市直江津地区）と関東平野を結ぶ陸上交通の抑えとして、また、魚野川を利用した河川交通の要所として、さらに魚沼の穀倉地帯を擁する経済上の要地として、重要な役割を担うこととなった。
sen.e: The Sakaｔo-jo castle where the clan used as its base played important roles because of the following reasons: It was located at a place enabling the control of overland traffic connecting Echigo-Fuchu (present Naoetsu area of Joetsu City) and Kanto Plain, was located at a strategic place in traffic using the Uono-gawa River and was also placed at a strategic place of the economy centered on the rice production in the Uonuma area.

The Sakato-jo castle which the clan used as its base played important roles because of the following reasons: It was located at a place enabling the control of overland traffic connecting Echigo-Fuchu (present Naoetsu area of Joetsu City) and the Kanto Plain, was located at a strategic place for traffic using the Uono-gawa River and was also at a strategic place economically, centering on rice production in the Uonuma area.

The Sakato-jo castle which the clan used as its base played important roles because of the following reasons: It was located at a place enabling the control of overland traffic connecting Echigo-Fuchu (present Naoetsu area of Joetsu City) and the Kanto Plain, was located at a strategic place for traffic using the Uono-gawa River and was also at a strategic place economically, centering on rice production in the Uonuma area.

sen.j: 守護代長尾為景は、永正4年（1507年）、越後の国人衆を糾合して守護上杉房能を排斥した。
sen.e: In 1507, Tamekage NAGAO, Shugodai, rallied Kokujin-shu (local samurais) in Echigo and expelled Fusayoshi UESUGI, Shugo.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In 1507, Tamekage NAGAO, the Shugodai, rallied Kokujin-shu (local samurai) in Echigo and expelled Fusayoshi UESUGI, the Shugo.
In 1507, Tamekage NAGAO, the Shugodai, rallied Kokujin-shu (local samurai) in Echigo and expelled Fusayoshi UESUGI, the Shugo.

sen.j: 永正7年（1510年）には関東管領上杉顕定をも長森原の戦いにおいて敗死させて越後一国に覇を唱えた。
sen.e: In 1510, Tamekage had Akisada UESUGI, Kanto Kanrei (a shogunal deputy for the Kanto region), killed in the Battle of Nagamorihara, holding sway in Echigo Province.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In 1510, Tamekage had Akisada UESUGI, Kanto Kanrei (a shogunal deputy for the Kanto region), killed in the Battle of Nagamorihara, allowing him to hold sway in Echigo Province.
In 1510, Tamekage had Akisada UESUGI, Kanto Kanrei (a shogunal deputy for the Kanto region), killed in the Battle of Nagamorihara, allowing him to hold sway in Echigo Province.

sen.j: 上田長尾氏は守護代長尾氏に対して一定の独立性を保持した。
sen.e: The UEDA NAGAO clan kept a certain amount of independence from the Nagao clan, Shugodai.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The UEDA NAGAO clan kept a certain amount of independence from the Nagao clan Shugodai.
The UEDA NAGAO clan kept a certain amount of independence from the Nagao clan, Shugodai.

sen.j: しかしながら、為景の死後、長尾景虎（上杉謙信）が越後国主となった。
sen.e: However, after the death of Tamekage, Kagetora NAGAO (Kenshin UESUGI) became Kokushu (head of provincial governors) of Echigo Province.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, after the death of Tamekage, Kagetora NAGAO (Kenshin UESUGI) became Kokushu (head of provincial governors) of Echigo Province.
However, after the death of Tamekage, Kagetora NAGAO (Kenshin UESUGI) became Kokushu (head of provincial governors) of Echigo Province.

sen.j: 天文 (元号)20年（1551年）には上田長尾氏の長尾政景が上杉謙信に坂戸城を包囲され、謙信に誓詞を提出して、その軍門に降ったとされる。
sen.e: Then, it is said that, with his Sakaｔo-jo castle surrounded by Kenshin UESUGI, Masakage NAGAO of the UEDA NAGAO clan surrendered to Kenshin in 1551, pledging his faith to him.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: It is said that with Sakato-jo castle surrounded by Kenshin UESUGI, Masakage NAGAO of the UEDA NAGAO clan surrendered to Kenshin in 1551, pledging his faith to him.
It is said that with Sakato-jo castle surrounded by Kenshin UESUGI, Masakage NAGAO of the UEDA NAGAO clan surrendered to Kenshin in 1551, pledging his faith to him.

sen.j: なお、その後、政景は立身するものの、永禄7年（1564年）、付近の野尻池にて琵琶嶋城主宇佐美定満との舟遊び中に定満とともに謎の死を遂げている。
sen.e: After that, Masakage was successful in his life, but met a mysterious death while boating with Sadamitsu USAMI, the lord of Biwajima-jo Castle, together with Sadamitsu.
After that, Masakage was successful in his life, but met a mysterious death while boating with Sadamitsu USAMI, the lord of Biwajima-jo Castle, who also perished.
After that, Masakage was successful in his life, but in 1564, he met a mysterious death while boating with Sadamitsu USAMI, the lord of Biwajima-jo Castle, who also perished.

sen.j: 謙信の死後、政景の子で謙信の養子となっていた上杉景勝が御館の乱を制して春日山城主になった。
sen.e: After the death of Kenshin, Kagekatsu UESUGI, who was a son of Masakage and had been adopted by Kenshin, wan Otate War and became the lord of Kasugayama-jo Castle.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: After the death of Kenshin, Kagekatsu UESUGI, who was a son of Masakage and had been adopted by Kenshin, won the Otate War and became the lord of Kasugayama-jo Castle.
After the death of Kenshin, Kagekatsu UESUGI, who was a son of Masakage and had been adopted by Kenshin, won the Otate War and became the lord of Kasugayama-jo Castle.

sen.j: すると、父が政景の家臣であった直江兼続（のちの直江兼続）をはじめとする「上田衆」が景勝の直臣団を構成するようになった。
sen.e: Then "Ueda-shu" (an Ueda-named group of vassals) including Kanetsugu NAOE (later Kanetsugu NAOE), whose father was a vassal of Masakage, became to form the trusted vassals of Kagekatsu.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Then "Ueda-shu" (an Ueda-named group of vassals) including Kanetsugu NAOE, whose father was a vassal of Masakage, formed a group of trusted vassals of Kagekatsu.
sen.cmt: Changed for clarity. I'm not sure why the name Kanetsugu NAOE was repeated as it adds no new information, so I have removed it.
sen.e: Then "Ueda-shu" (an Ueda-named group of vassals) including Kanetsugu NAOE, whose father was a vassal of Masakage, formed a group of trusted vassals of Kagekatsu.

sen.j: 同時に、坂戸城は、春日山城の有力な支城として領国経営の重要拠点となった。
sen.e: At the same time, Sakato-jo Castle became a strategic site for managing the territory as an important branch castle of Kasugayma-jo Castle.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: At the same time, Sakato-jo Castle became a strategic site for managing the territory as an important branch castle of Kasugayma-jo Castle.
At the same time, Sakato-jo Castle became a strategic site for managing the territory as an important branch castle of Kasugayma-jo Castle.

sen.j: 兼続も坂戸城主に任じられている。
sen.e: Kanetsugu was appointed to the lord of Sakato-jo Castle as well.
Kanetsugu was also appointed as lord of Sakato-jo Castle.
Kanetsugu was also appointed as lord of Sakato-jo Castle.

sen.j: 景勝は、天正10年（1582年）に越中国方面で織田信長の軍勢と交戦した。
sen.e: In 1582, Kagetatsu fought with a troop of Nobunaga ODA in aｎ area of Ecchu Province.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In 1582, Kagetatsu fought with Nobunaga ODA's troops in an area of Ecchu Province.
In 1582, Kagekatsu fought with Nobunaga ODA's troops in an area of Ecchu Province.

sen.j: その際、上野国厩橋城（群馬県前橋市）から越後に侵入した滝川一益の軍勢とも戦っているが坂戸城は持ちこたえている。
sen.e: At that time, his troop also fought with that of Kazumasu TAKIGAWA who intruded into Echigo from Maebashi-jo Castle in Kozuke Province, managing to defend Sakato-jo Castle.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: At that time, his troops also fought with those of Kazumasu TAKIGAWA who invaded Echigo from Maebashi-jo Castle in Kozuke Province, and managed to successfully defend Sakato-jo Castle.
At that time, his troops also fought with those of Kazumasu TAKIGAWA who invaded Echigo from Maebashi-jo Castle in Kozuke Province, and managed to successfully defend Sakato-jo Castle.

sen.j: 慶長3年（1598年）、景勝は陸奥国の会津地方に転封となり、かわって越前国から堀秀治が越後に入部した。
sen.e: In 1598, Kagekatsu's territory was changed to the Aizu area of Mutsu Province, and Hideharu HORI moved to Echigo from Echizen Province.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In 1598, Kagekatsu's territory was changed to the Aizu area of Mutsu Province, and Hideharu HORI moved to Echigo from Echizen Province.
In 1598, Kagekatsu's territory was changed to the Aizu area of Mutsu Province, and Hideharu HORI moved to Echigo from Echizen Province.

sen.j: 坂戸城には、秀治の家臣堀直寄が入り、上田3万石を領した。
sen.e: Then Naoyori HORI, a vassal of Hideyoshi became the lord of Sakato-jo Castle, making the Ueda area with a rice production of 30 thousand Koku (approx. 10 liters/Koku) his territory.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Then Naoyori HORI, a vassal of Hideyoshi, became the lord of Sakato-jo Castle, making the Ueda area with a rice production of 30 thousand Koku (1 koku is approximately 10 liters) his territory.
Then Naoyori HORI, a vassal of Hideyoshi, became the lord of Sakato-jo Castle, making the Ueda area with a rice production of 30 thousand Koku (1 koku is approximately 10 liters) his territory.

sen.j: 直寄は坂戸城を山麓の居館部を中心に近世城郭へと改修している。
sen.e: Naoyori modified Sakato-jo Castle, centered on the residential part at the foot of the mountain, so that the castle became the one in the early-modern times.
Naoyori modified Sakato-jo Castle, centering on the residential part at the foot of the mountain, so that the castle became of the style of early-modern times.
Naoyori modified Sakato-jo Castle, centering on the residential part at the foot of the mountain, so that the castle became of the style of early-modern times.

sen.j: 慶長15年（1610年）堀直寄が信濃国飯山に移されたのち、坂戸城は廃却された。
sen.e: Sakato-jo Castle was abolished after Naoyori HORI was moved to Iiyama of Shinano Province in 1610.
Sakato-jo Castle was demolished after Naoyori HORI was moved to Iiyama in Shinano Province in 1610.
Sakato-jo Castle was demolished after Naoyori HORI was moved to Iiyama in Shinano Province in 1610.

sen.j: 室町時代の坂戸が、交通上、経済上の要地であったことは上述の通りである。
sen.e: It is described above that, in the Muromachi period, Sakato was a strategic site of traffic and economy.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: As described above, in the Muromachi Period Sakato was a strategic site as regards transport and the economy.
As described above, in the Muromachi Period Sakato was a strategic site as regards transport and the economy.

sen.j: さらに同時代にあっては、越後国も上野国もともに関東管領山内上杉家の分国だったため、関越間の交通もまた頻繁だったことがある。
sen.e: In addition, since both of Echigo Province and Kozuke Province were, at that period, under control of the Yamauchi Uesugi family, Kanto Kanrei (a shogunal deputy for the Kanto region), traffic between Echigo and Kanto was busy.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In addition, since both Echigo Province and Kozuke Province were, at that period, under the control of the Yamauchi Uesugi family, who were Kanto Kanrei (shogunal deputy for the Kanto region), traffic between Echigo and Kanto was frequent.

In addition, since both Echigo Province and Kozuke Province were, at that period, under the control of the Yamauchi Uesugi family, who were Kanto Kanrei (shogunal deputy for the Kanto region), traffic between Echigo and Kanto was frequent.

sen.j: 当時の魚沼地方には上田銀山があって越後随一の銀の産出をほこってもいた。
sen.e: Furthermore, Ueda Ginzan Silver Mine in the Uonuma area produced a largest amount of silver in Echizo at that time as well.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Furthermore, Ueda Ginzan Silver Mine in the Uonuma area produced the largest amount of silver in Echizo at that time.
Furthermore, Ueda Ginzan Silver Mine in the Uonuma area produced the largest amount of silver in Echizo at that time.

sen.j: こうしたことは、戦国時代 (日本)に入ると、また激しい争奪の対象ともなったことを意味していた。
sen.e: These situationｓ indicated that, entering the Sengoku period (period of warring states) (in Japan), furious battles occurred targeting for capturing this area.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: These factors meant that, entering the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States), furious battles occurred targeting the capture of this area.
These factors meant that, entering the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States), furious battles occurred targeting the capture of this area.

sen.j: その軍事拠点たる坂戸城は、魚野川をはさんで、三国街道を見下ろす坂戸山に立地している。
sen.e: Sakato-jo Castle, its strategic military site, was located on Sakato-yama Mountain that commanded a view of the Mikuni-kaido road across the Uono-gawa River.
Sakato-jo Castle was located on Sakato-yama Mountain which commanded a view of the Mikuni-kaido road across the Uono-gawa River, and was a strategic military site.
Sakato-jo Castle was located on Sakato-yama Mountain which commanded a view of the Mikuni-kaido road across the Uono-gawa River, and was a strategic military site.

sen.j: 坂戸山は、山麓との比高は400ｍを超え、六日町盆地を流れる魚野川と三国川の合流点に向かって半島状に突出している。
sen.e: Sakato-yama Mountain, with a height of exceeding 400 meters from its foot, protrudes, like a peninsula, towards the place where the Uono-gawa River and the Mikuni-gawa River, both of which flow through the Muikamachi basin, meet.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Sakato-yama Mountain, with a height in excess of 400 meters from its base, protrudes like a peninsula towards the place where the Uono-gawa River and the Mikuni-gawa River, both of which flow through the Muikamachi basin, meet.

Sakato-yama Mountain, with a height in excess of 400 meters from its base, protrudes like a peninsula towards the place where the Uono-gawa River and the Mikuni-gawa River, both of which flow through the Muikamachi basin, meet.

sen.j: 北、東、西の三方は急崖をなし、西裾を流れる魚野川が天然の外堀として軍事上の防禦線となっている。
sen.e: Its north, east and west sides are provided with steep cliffs, and the Uono-gawa River flow at the west-side foot of the mountain constitutes a natural moat, providing a military defense line.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Its north, east and west sides are steep cliffs, and the Uono-gawa River flowing at the west-side of the mountain constitutes a natural moat, providing a military defense line.
Its north, east and west sides are steep cliffs, and the Uono-gawa River flowing at the west-side of the mountain constitutes a natural moat, providing a military defense line.

sen.j: 西麓の緩斜面に、城主の居館跡と家臣団の屋敷跡がある。
sen.e: Ｉn the slightly sloping area at the west foot of the mountain, there are remains of the lord's residence and those of the residences of the vassals.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The slightly sloping area at the western foot of the mountain contains the remnants of the lord's residence and those of the residences of the vassals.
The slightly sloping area at the western foot of the mountain contains the remnants of the lord's residence and those of the residences of the vassals.

sen.j: 東西110メートル、南北80メートルの城主居館跡は矩形をなし、その周囲は土塁がめぐらされている。
sen.e: The remains of the lord's residence are rectangular, 110 meters in the east-west direction and 80 meters in the north-south direction, and the residence area was surrounded by earthworks.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The remains of the lord's residence are rectangular, 110 meters in the east-west direction and 80 meters in the north-south direction, and the residential area was surrounded by earthworks.
The remains of the lord's residence are rectangular, 110 meters in the east-west direction and 80 meters in the north-south direction, and the residential area was surrounded by earthworks.

sen.j: 特に西側正面には、高さ約2メートルの石垣がきわめて良好に遺存している。
sen.e: In particular, a approx. 2-meter high stone wall on the western front side remains in a quite good state.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In particular, an approximately 2-meter high stone wall on the western front side remains in good condition.
In particular, an approximately 2-meter high stone wall on the western front side remains in good condition.

sen.j: なお、家臣屋敷跡の前面、魚野川との間には「埋田」（うめた）と称される堀跡が残っている。
sen.e: There are remains of a moat called "Umeta" (literally, a buried paddy field) between the front side of the remains of residences of vassals and the Uono-gawa River.
There are remains of a moat called "Umeta" (literally, buried paddy field) between the front side of the remains of the residences of vassals and the Uono-gawa River.
There are remains of a moat called "Umeta" (literally, buried paddy field) between the front side of the remains of the residences of vassals and the Uono-gawa River.

sen.j: 城主居館跡の南方、「薬師尾根」と称される尾根の中腹には「中屋敷」跡と呼ばれる東西約40メートル、南北約50メートルの区画がある。
sen.e: A lot, called remains of "Naka-yashiki" (literally, a middle residence), with the size of approx. 40 meters in the east-west direction and approx. 50 meters in the north-south direction, exists in the middle of a ridge called "Yakushi-one" (Yakusi ridge) in the south of the remains of the lord's residence.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: A section called "Naka-yashiki" (literally, middle residence) remains, with a length of approximately 40 meters in the east-west direction and approximately 50 meters in the north-south direction, exists in the middle of a ridge called "Yakushi-one" (Yakushi ridge) to the south of the remains of the lord's residence.

A section called "Naka-yashiki" (literally, middle residence) remains, with a length of approximately 40 meters in the east-west direction and approximately 50 meters in the north-south direction, exists in the middle of a ridge called "Yakushi-one" (Yakushi ridge) to the south of the remains of the lord's residence.

sen.j: また、居館跡から東方、山上の尾根に向かう大手道を上った通称「桃の木平」には東西30メートル、南北120メートルと長狭な「上屋敷」跡がある。
sen.e: In addition, remains of ""Kami-yashiki" (literally, an upper residence), with a long and narrow shape of 30 meters in the east-west direction and 120 meters in the north-south direction, exist in so-called "Momonoki-daira" (literally, a peach plain), which can be reached by climbing up Ootemichi (the road to the main gate to the castle) towards the mountain ridge, in the east of the remains of the lord's residence.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In addition, the remains of the "Kami-yashiki" (literally, upper residence), with a long and narrow shape, 30 meters long in the east-west direction and 120 meters in the north-south direction, exist in the so-called "Momonoki-daira" (literally, peach plain), which can be reached by climbing up Ootemichi (the road to the main gate to the castle) towards the mountain ridge, to the east of the remains of the lord's residence.

In addition, the remains of the "Kami-yashiki" (literally, upper residence), with a long and narrow shape, 30 meters long in the east-west direction and 120 meters in the north-south direction, exist in the so-called "Momonoki-daira" (literally, peach tree plain), which can be reached by climbing up Ootemichi (the road to the main gate to the castle) towards the mountain ridge, to the east of the remains of the lord's residence.

sen.j: 戦闘時に使用する坂戸山頂上付近の「本丸」は、標高634メートルの平坦地にあった。
sen.e: Honmaru (the keep of the castle), which was located around the top of the mountain and was used in battles, was placed in a flat area at 634 meters above sea level.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The Honmaru (the keep of the castle), which was located near the top of the mountain and was used in battles, was constructed on a flat area at 634 meters above sea level.
The Honmaru (the keep of the castle), which was located near the top of Sakato-yama Mountain and was used in battles, was constructed on a flat area at 634 meters above sea level.

sen.j: それほど高所に位置するわけではないが、湧水が7合目付近でも得られることから、戦略上の価値はきわめて高かったと推定される。
sen.e: Although being not located in so high a place, the Honmaru is supposed to have had a high military value, because spring was available even around the height of 7 go-me (70% of the height of the mountain)
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Although not being located in such a high place, the Honmaru is supposed to have had a high military value because spring water was available even at the height of 7 go-me (70% of the height of the mountain)

Although not being located in such a high place, the Honmaru is supposed to have had a high military value because spring water was available even at the height of 7 go-me (70% of the height of the mountain)

sen.j: 「本丸」から北に延びる尾根上に「二の丸」「三の丸」などと称される主要郭跡が残っている。
sen.e: Remains of some of the main buildings, called "Ninomaru" (the second fortress tower) and "Sannomaru" (the third fortress tower), exist on the ridge extending to the north from the "Honmaru."
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Remains of some of the main buildings, called "Ninomaru" (the second fortress tower) and "Sannomaru" (the third fortress tower), exist on the ridge extending to the north from the "Honmaru."
Remains of some of the main buildings, called "Ninomaru" (the second fortress tower) and "Sannomaru" (the third fortress tower), exist on the ridge extending to the north from the "Honmaru."

sen.j: そのほか、南東方向の搦手にも郭跡がみられる。
sen.e: In addition, remains of some buildings are also found on the back-gate side in the southeast of the "Honmaru."
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In addition, the remains of some buildings are also visible to the back-gate side to the southeast of the "Honmaru."
In addition, the remains of some buildings are also visible to the back-gate side to the southeast of the "Honmaru."

sen.j: 南東尾根の先端、標高631メートル地点には「詰の丸」と呼称される平坦地があり、土塁が遺存している。
sen.e: A flat land area called "Tsumenomaru" exists in a place of 631 meters above sea level at the tip of the southeast ridge, and remains of earthworks exist there.
An area of flat land called "Tsumenomaru" exists in a place 631 meters above sea level at the tip of the southeast ridge, and earthwork remains can be found there.
An area of flat land called "Tsumenomaru" exists in a place 631 meters above sea level at the tip of the southeast ridge, and earthwork remains can be found there.

sen.j: なお、山上尾根の要所には大規模な堀切があり、また、「本丸」東方斜面には石垣が遺存する。
sen.e: Large-scale trenches are provided at strategic points on the mountain ridge, and remains of stone walls exist on the east-side slope of the "Honmaru."
Large-scale trenches are seen at strategic points on the mountain ridge, and remains of stone walls exist on the east-side slope of the "Honmaru."
Large-scale trenches are seen at strategic points on the mountain ridge, and remains of stone walls exist on the east-side slope of the "Honmaru."

sen.j: このほか、山頂から南西に延びる尾根の標高500メートル地点付近には「西の丸」跡がある。
sen.e: In addition, remains of "Nishinomaru" (the west-side fortress tower) exist around a place at a height of 500 meters above sea level on the ridge extending from the mountain peak to southwest.
In addition, remains of the "Nishinomaru" (the west-side fortress tower) can be found at a height of 500 meters above sea level on the ridge extending from the mountain peak to the southwest.
In addition, remains of the "Nishinomaru" (the west-side fortress tower) can be found at a height of 500 meters above sea level on the ridge extending from the mountain peak to the southwest.

sen.j: 「西の丸」から尾根先端、寺ヶ鼻の「出丸」跡までの約2キロメートルの間に100基以上の畝状竪堀が築かれている。
sen.e: More than 100 of unejo tatebori (a series of parallel trenches running up the sides of the mountain) were constructed over approx. 2-km from the "Nishinomaru" to "Demaru" (a fortress tower built far from the main castle).

More than 100 unejo tatebori (a series of parallel trenches running up the sides of the mountain) were constructed over approximately 2kilometers from the "Nishinomaru" to the "Demaru" (a fortress tower built far from the main castle).

More than 100 unejo tatebori (a series of parallel trenches running up the sides of the mountain) were constructed over approximately 2 kilometers from the "Nishinomaru" to the "Demaru" (a fortress tower built far from the main castle) at Teragahana, the tip of the ridge.
sen.cmt: 「尾根先端、寺ヶ鼻の」の部分を追加。

sen.j: 坂戸山の山麓には長尾政景墓所と上杉景勝・直江兼続の生誕碑がある。
sen.e: At the foot of Sakato-yama Mountain, the grave of Masakage NAGAO and the monument commemorating the birth of Kagekatsu UESUGI and Kanetsugu NAOE are located.
At the foot of Sakato-yama Mountain, the grave of Masakage NAGAO and a monument commemorating the birth of Kagekatsu UESUGI and Kanetsugu NAOE are located.
At the foot of Sakato-yama Mountain, the grave of Masakage NAGAO and a monument commemorating the birth of Kagekatsu UESUGI and Kanetsugu NAOE are located.

sen.j: また、山頂には天正14年（1586年）、直江兼続の勧請によるとの伝承をもつ富士権現が祀られている。
sen.e: Fuji Gongen Shrine, which was said was built in 1586 through Kanjo (praying for the coming of a deity) by Kanetsugu NAOE, is located at the top of the mountain.
Fuji Gongen Shrine, which was said to have been built in 1586 through Kanjo (praying for the coming of a deity) by Kanetsugu NAOE, is located at the top of the mountain.
Fuji Gongen Shrine, which was said to have been built in 1586 through Kanjo (praying for the coming of a deity) by Kanetsugu NAOE, is located at the top of the mountain.

sen.j: 現在、坂戸山は登山道が整備され、多くのハイカーで賑わっている。
sen.e: Today, good roads are provided for climbing Sakato-yama Mountain, and the mountain is visited by many hikers.
Today, there are good roads for climbing Sakato-yama Mountain, and many hikers visit.
Today, there are good roads for climbing Sakato-yama Mountain, and many hikers visit.

sen.j: 山開きは毎年6月30日におこなわれる。
sen.e: A ceremony for announcing the start of the season of climbing the mountain is held on June 30 every year.
A ceremony announcing the start of the climbing season is held on June 30 every year.
A ceremony announcing the start of the climbing season is held on June 30 every year.

sen.j: 坂戸山の山麓周辺一帯には、現在、旧六日町の温泉街や市街地が広がっている。
sen.e: The vast areas around the foot of Sakato-yama Mountain now become hot-spring districts and urban areas of former Muikamachi Town.
The vast areas around the foot of Sakato-yama Mountain have now become hot-spring districts and urban areas of the former Muikamachi Town.
The vast areas around the foot of Sakato-yama Mountain have now become hot-spring districts and urban areas of the former Muikamachi Town.

sen.e: Sakado, Muika-machi, Minamiuonuma City, Nigata Prefecture

sen.e: Kanetsu Expressway

sen.j: -六日町インターチェンジから車で約10分
sen.e: - About ten minutes by car from the Muikamachi interchange

sen.j: -六日町駅から車で約5分
